title: Everything you need to know about Spain controversial coach Jorge Vilda and the feud with his players that tainted their World Cup run
body_text:
Everything you need to know about Spain's controversial coach Jorge Vilda ‚Äî and the feud with his players that's tainted their World Cup run
Spain's women's national team has punched its ticket to the 2023 World Cup final.
The players have thrived on the field despite a public feud with their coach, Jorge Vilda.
Players who complained about their management's tactics were threatened with a 5-year disqualification.
Spain's women's national team, "La Roja," has advanced to its first-ever World Cup final.
And they have done so without several of their top stars.
Just 10 months before the 2023 World Cup kicked off Down Under, 15 players who had regularly appeared on Spain's roster sent identical emails to the Royal Spanish Football Federation (RFEF) calling for an overhaul of the team's management.
The players ‚Äî who have since become known as "Las 15" ‚Äî vowed to boycott the national team, accusing management of poor treatment that posed a threat to their mental and physical health.
The feud makes for a bittersweet World Cup experience for the 2023 finalists, who are playing under a coach towards whom they are visibly hostile. Videos show players swatting him away, and celebrating separately.
Players said management was excessively controlling ‚Äî and forced them to leave their hotel rooms unlocked
Many of Las 15's complaints centered around longtime head coach Jorge Vilda, who the athletes allege fostered an environment that "significantly" impacted their physical and mental health in a negative manner.
They voiced concerns regarding the staff's tactical knowledge, the quality of training, and physical care provided to the players.
They also described the controlling nature of the team's management. Until 2019, members of the squad were required to leave their hotel rooms unlocked so the coaching staff could complete bed checks, The Athletic reported.
"We want a firm commitment towards a professional project in which all aspects are taken care of to get the best performances out of a group of players who we consider can achieve more and better objectives," the players later said in a group statement shared on Twitter.
Coach Jorge Vilda (a nepo baby) called the complaints 'a farce'
Players questioned Vilda's qualifications for the role of senior national team coach as they began their revolt.
Vilda's father, √Ångel Vilda, is highly influential in Spanish soccer. While his influence on Jorge's career has never been confirmed, local media reports speculate that nepotism played a role in his ascent. (√Ångel has denied helping his son.)
More in Sports
The younger Vilda rose up the coaching ranks fast. The Madrid native stepped into his first head coaching position with Spain's U-17 national team in 2009. In 2014, he assumed the helm for the U-19 side. Just one season later, in 2015, he was appointed to his current post.
Fast-forward to 2022, Vilda fiercely rejected his players' complaints. He refused to step down from his position at the front of the bench. In a fiery press conference just days after the emails went out, the 42-year-old called the situation "a farce on the world stage."
"I don't wish what I'm going through these days on anyone," he added. "You cannot throw the stone and hide your hand."
Players faced a 5-year disqualification for voicing their complaints
Though Las 15 insisted that they intended to keep the contents of their emails to the RFEF "private," its president, Luis Rubiales, made a public response.
The federation wrote that it refused "to accept any type of pressure from any player" and called on the 15 athletes to "ask for forgiveness" if they wished to return to the national team.
Rubiales and company also threatened retribution against the participating players; their protest against the team's management style constituted a "very serious infraction," their statement read, and could "carry sanctions of two and five years of disqualification" from La Roja.
The RFEF also unequivocally backed Vilda, accusing the players of questioning "the continuity of the national team and its coaching staff" in a way that "is not within their powers."
Las 15 includes some of the best players in the world
Seven of the 15 players who took action against the federation came from FC Barcelona ‚Äî the club that won this year's Champions League title in front of record-setting crowds. The rest are also widely regarded as top-class players.

When it came to the World Cup, eight of these players declared themselves eligible for the World Cup. Vilda selected just three of them ‚Äî Bonmati, Caldentey, and Batlle ‚Äî leaving some of the world's best players out of the roster.
Seven players refused to be considered, including Le√≥n, who said: "It will really piss me off not to go to the World Cup. But my values come first."
Several US Women's National Team stars ‚Äî who had their own feud with their federation over equal pay and treatment ‚Äî spoke out in support of the Spanish players, too. Forward Megan Rapinoe said she's "with the players 100%."
Spain's natural talent is shining through at the World Cup
Spain's success is a reflection of the immense talent, and depth, on the roster.
The squad has built-in chemistry, as the majority of his players have spent years competing together at the club level; eight members of the current World Cup squad play for Barcelona, while another eight play for Real Madrid.
Laia Cervello Herrero, a Barcelona beat reporter, told Al Jazeera that may be masking Vilda's lack of tactical prowess. "It is easier to take the skeleton of a winning team and transfer it to the national team," Herrero said. "It gives you more guarantees."
Vilda claims the tumult within his ranks is behind them and that he now boasts "great unity" with his squad, as he said in a press conference after the semi-final.
But there are signs that the strain between the coach and his players remain, including this viral clip of Vilda celebrating solo following Spain's quarter-final win over the Netherlands:

A 2023 World Cup win could empower the players' movement ‚Äî but it could also work against their protest
Spain has never won the women's World Cup.
If they beat England on Sunday, each Spanish player gets $270,000 (pocket change for male soccer stars, but life-changing money for many women's players) plus the trophy.
There could be another prize: Some, including USWNT star Christen Press, argue that the players could gain more leverage over Vilda if they become world champions.
But there's also a reality in which the RFEF views an historic win as a testament to Vilda's skill, and further extends his tenure.
Spain's championship match against England kicks off in Sydney Sunday at 6 a.m. ET (8 p.m. local time). Fans stateside can tune in to watch the action on FOX.
